title: Still tied ahead of the debates
text:
— The Green Party is looking at its best shot ever to pick up seats federally this month, as its leader works to persuade voters to embrace a minority government that she says could move the needle decisively on climate policy. Still, polling has yet to show signs of a significant Green “wave” building in Canada.

C’EST LUNDI — Welcome to POLITICO Pro Canada’s morning newsletter, where we see Prime Minister Justin Trudeau getting a double-whammy in this side-eye piece in satirical site The Onion.

Send news tips and song requests to lgardner@politico.com, apanetta@politico.com and cboudreau@politico.com, or on Twitter @Gardner_LM, @Alex_Panetta and @ceboudreau.

“You want to get messed up? / When the times get rough / Put your favorite record on baby / And fill the bathtub up”

THE GREAT DEBATE — It’s debate night in Ottawa (well, technically in Gatineau, but your hosts digress), where six party leaders will each make their case to the English-speaking electorate, all on one stage. If any of them is going to break out from the pack, tonight could prove pivotal.

— Where things stand: The race remains deadlocked between the Liberals and the Conservatives, according to an aggregate of national polls, Lauren writes.

There has been some movement, however. The Bloc Quebecois pushed ahead of the Tories in Quebec after last week’s French-language debate, a development that could spell trouble for Conservatives, who need pickups in the province to stand a chance at forming government.

— Get instant analysis: Your Pro Canada team will be following tonight’s debate live alongside POLITICO’s Ryan Heath, who will be on the ground in Ottawa. Join us for the live chat here: politico.com/canadadebate.

CATCH A WAVE — Alex and Lauren each took a look at two phenomena that could profoundly affect the balance of power in Ottawa after Oct. 21: Quebec’s restive voting record and the ascendance of the Green Party in Canada’s western and eastern corners.

— Trudeau’s fickle firewall: Trudeau’s perilous path to reelection this fall runs through Canada’s version of a swing state on steroids: Quebec.

The province is living up to its reputation for wild races, with the Bloc Québécois surging past the Conservatives into the No. 2 spot and making for tight, unpredictable three-way fights between the Liberals, Conservatives and Bloc in a series of ridings.

Alex profiles the zany voting history of his home province, whose past elections have included cases in which five college students were elected and an Ottawa bartender who struggled with French wound up as an MP in rural francophone Quebec.

— Perspective: Imagine a 335-seat wave in the U.S. House of Representatives, in which the Libertarian or Green party catapults into first place within weeks and wins a historic landslide. That’s what happened in Quebec in 1984, 1993, 2011 and 2015. Each time, a different party went from nowhere to taking between two-thirds and three-quarters of the seats.

— Liberals watching nervously: Trudeau can only afford to lose eight seats to retain his parliamentary majority, and he’d be defeated entirely if he loses too many more. Quebec happens to be the one populous region where the Liberals might not only hold onto huge numbers, but potentially even make gains. “It comes down to math,” one Liberal official said, speaking of Quebec. “And the fruit is ripe there.”

— It’s a bit easier being Green: May has largely bounced between the Greens’ stronghold in Vancouver and Vancouver Island and Atlantic Canada during the campaign, stumping for votes in areas where strong provincial showings by the party could yield federal seats later this month.

Although polling isn’t predicting a wave, May is banking on voter disenchantment with the establishment parties — and growing concern about the effects of climate change — to move more votes into her party’s column on Oct. 21, Lauren writes.

— Growth opportunity: Her party is expected to increase its representation up from 2 currently in the House of Commons. That could help it play kingmaker of sorts after election day, depending on how the balance of power shakes out.

May wouldn’t commit to how the Greens would or wouldn’t work with the other parties to form government, except to say the party wouldn’t abandon its commitment to meeting certain stringent carbon reduction benchmarks.

“There is no inevitability about who leads a political party into the next Parliament,” May told Lauren last month, just minutes after Trudeau made his first statement apologizing for photos showing him wearing brownface.

PRUDENT TECHNOPHILES — An exclusive POLITICO/Abacus Data poll casts Canadians as prudent technophiles. About 45 percent strongly or somewhat support the development of Artificial Intelligence tools, while 29 percent strongly or somewhat oppose AI's development. Only 18 percent of Canadians fear losing a job to A.I.

Abacus Data CEO David Coletto said this gives policy-makers some leash to develop these tools, but warns global opinion can shift quickly, as it did with social media giants and privacy issues.

— Huawei factor: The survey says 36 percent of Canadians believe Chinese telecom firm Huawei should not be allowed to participate in developing the country's 5G network, 25 percent say it should be allowed, and 39 percent don't have clear views.

Coletto says the ambiguous state of public opinion make a tough decision on Huawei even tougher for the Canadian government. The Trudeau government has delayed a 5G decision until after the election. The Conservatives say they’d ban Huawei from the network.

“Canada is being put between two superpowers and being forced to decide [between angering the U.S. or China],” Coletto said. “And the public is not making it any easier for them.”

— The New York Times profiled Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer over the weekend, leading with a sore subject for some in American politics: crowd size.

— A Conservative Party spokesperson confirmed Scheer is registered with the U.S. Selective Service, the agency that runs the American military draft. The revelation comes amid the news that the Conservative leader has dual Canadian and U.S. citizenship. CBC News.

— The Trudeau government is appealing a ruling from the Canadian Human Rights Tribunal to pay C$2 billion to Indigenous children and their families in compensation for forced removals and a chronically underfunded child welfare system. The Indigenous Services minister said he was hoping for a stay of the ruling to consider next steps outside of an election season. Canadian Press.

— Former NDP Leader Thomas Mulcair said current Leader Jagmeet Singh has “totally abandoned” party principles by supporting Quebec’s ability to enact the controversial religious symbols legislation Bill 21. Mulcair suffered in the 2015 election by standing up for Muslim women’s right to wear a niqab. CTV News.

— Singh slammed the Green Party and refused demands to apologize after stating the party’s candidates did not have a clear position on abortion rights. NDP candidates have raised stances on abortion in an attempt to provide contrasts with Green positions in competitive ridings. Canadian Press.

— The president and CEO of a publicly traded tech firm writes a first-person account of how government programs like an initiative to nurture A.I. funding and good immigration policies helped persuade his company to move from Silicon Valley to Canada. Venture Beat.
